text:
When we think carcinogens, we usually think
cigarettes and asbestos, but the reality of

the situation is that the most common carcinogen
in the world is next to impossible to avoid
- that’s right folks, it’s sunlight.

While the sun blasts us with an intense flood
of energetic particles: both visible and hot

infrared, it’s the ultraviolet rays that
we should be worried about.

Today we’re talking radiation folks and
our body’s built-in chemical defense systems,

one of which happens to be that lobster suit
of yours.

Broad spectrum UV radiation is comprised of
these three types (UVA - 315 to 400 nm, UVB

A small minority of the sun’s energy comes
as UV, and the Earth’s atmosphere cuts out

most of that, completely eliminating any UVC
radiation from the mix.
At ground level, 95% is UVA and 5% is UVB.

This is a really good thing because UVB and
UVC are more directly connected to skin cancers.

UVA, due to its unfettered intensity when
piercing through the atmosphere does deep,

long-term damage to the skin, causing aging
and wrinkles.

UVB on the other hand has some serious cytotoxic
and mutagenic effects on the skin.

When UVB photons come in contact with skin
cells, they can strike into DNA molecules.

Now, a DNA molecule can dissipate some energy
as heat; however, being hit by a UV photon

causes it to enter an excited state, meaning
it has extra energy that could make it more
reactive.

While in this state, a handful of different
mutations may occur.

One common mutation involves the erroneous
fusion of base pairs in the DNA chain that
creates a freaky bulge (will visualize this).

This bulge is harder for DNA’s repair systems
to detect, and it may change the way that

the DNA encodes proteins, potentially leading
to cancer.

Now, obviously folks, nature didn’t come
up with sun tan lotion, but instead came up

with two brilliant chemical UV defense systems
of its own – tans and sunburns.

Skin contains a pigment called melanin which
makes it dark.
The darker the skin, the more melanin.

The skin cells that produce melanin, called
melanocytes, respond to UV radiation by going

into melanin overdrive, which darkens the
skin.

The melanin absorbs that UV and dissipates
the energy as heat, protecting your DNA.

For perspective, one study found that a black
skin will let in only 7.4% of UVB and 17.5%

of UVA radiation, whereas, white skin lets
in 24% of UVB and 55% of UVA.

So while darker skin offers higher protection,
it isn’t perfect so I don’t care who you
are, bring that sunscreen!
What if the melanin isn’t enough?

What if the sun’s rays are too plentiful,
too powerful?

Skin cells are pretty selfless little guys
and would do anything for you, and although

you may be flattered, that red hue on your
face isn’t you blushing.

In short, a sunburn is a toxic reaction to
overexposure to UVB radiation.

When your body starts feeling the heat , it
floods the area with blood to help heal the
damaged cells.

If the cells can’t be repaired, they end
up sacrificing themselves for the greater

good, and thus you might notice some dry,
peeling skin when your sunburn heals itself.

Keep in mind folks, these two defense systems
aren’t perfect, and sometimes mutations

can remain in your skin and eventually grow
into cancer.

So really, be smart out there and use your
sunscreen.
